description: Excellent people and NB neighborhood bar. Got a lot of help here one night when my car was locked up in a garage up the street.
author: Phauking R.

description:
This is a classic San Francisco watering hole where mobsters used to get together to figure out who should be wearing a cement overcoat and thrown into the bay. Apparently Joltin' Joe DiMaggio used to come here thus answering Simon & Garfunkel's age-old question in "Mrs. Robinson", "Where have you gone, Joe DiMaggio?" This corner spot has that old school vibe like Bogey came in looking for the Maltese Falcon, and the vintage feeling was made complete by the veteran bartender who takes no prisoners when he's hurling insults at every customer who walks in (photo: http://bit.ly/2C4tW9z).

Regulars take it in stride, while others, mostly foreign tourists, were confused or scared off much to the amusement of the bartender. It looked like he bused the tables only when he felt like it, which likely explains why nobody sat at them. Everybody was crowded around the bar (photo: http://bit.ly/2o9wkmU) including us who ordered a couple of refreshing pints of Guinness (photo: http://bit.ly/2BAsbQo) before heading to Fior d'Italia for dinner. Do I recommend La Rocca's Corner for your patronage? If you want to go where people know, where people are all the same. You want to go where everybody knows your name. But not ours. Norm!

BEER - 5 stars...cheap and when is Guinness not 5 stars?
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...old-timey but not really charming
SERVICE - 3 stars...he instills fear
TOTAL - 3 stars...how do you like your cement overcoat?
author: Ed U.

description:
Low key corner sports/dive bar with room to sit in game days and a diverse clientele on those days (everybody from screaming fans wearing jerseys to Mandarin speaking couples wearing lace and a suit).
The German lady is nice, but the angry looking guy not so much.
author: Dennis W.

description:
I have to admit that I hadn't ever been to La Rocca's Corner until a couple weeks ago and boy, it's a great dive bar. My friends who live in North Beach are regulars at this place and I can totally see why. $3 dollar beers, great well spirits, a few TVs and a nice calm dive bar attitude. 

It's a great place to grab a couple cheap drinks pre Cobb's comedy show and watch some of the bay area sports teams. You'll find a bunch of regulars in there along with some visiting tourists making their way up from Fisherman's Wharf so, it's a nice mixed crew of patrons. 

Solid dive. It's not a destination by any means but, if you're in the neighborhood, it's a great option.
author: Benjamin F.

description:
$6 beers!! Stopped here for a beer before cobbs comedy club, since it's down th street!

A true dive bar with a jukebox playing oldies. There are 4 TVs playing various sports and it does seem like there are a lot of locals here. Not too crowded at all! 

The cash register is ancient and I'm really surprised it actually works. Framed posters inhabit the walls. Stop in. Why not
author: Anmy V.

description: Talk about a fun place. Very good prices on drinks - less than most small towns, and that isn't something you find in SF. Tanya was such a friendly bartender, handled everything like a pro and poured a stiff drink. Good mix of locals and tourists looking to have a good drink and socialize. Easy place to talk to people and have a good time!  I'll make this one of my go-to places going forward. It's worth coming for a drink and to take a step back in time and relax. Do it!
author: Matthew S.

description: Great Bloody Marys. Johnny is a great bartender. The patrons are welcoming. I'm so glad I decided to pop in.
author: Kyle M.

description: This is a nice neighborhood bar that gets locals and tourist alike. I had a few Guinness Stouts and enjoyed the l laid back atmosphere.
author: David F.

description: This is myyyyyy type of place. Super friendly staff and nice stiff drinks. It's that type of "dive bar" that is a level above an actual dive. You don't feel outclassed but you don't feel dirty. It has subtle hints of nostalgia from the old school cash register to the generic coffee maker. But then a complete juxtaposition because they have a very nice espresso machine. They also have chargers to charge up your phone which is a nice touch for a tourist out and about. If you go make sure Tonya pours you...she's the best!!! And Johnie behind the bar takes that extra care.  Will definitely be back!!
author: Kerin S.

description: Came here on a Saturday and walked up on a high school fundraiser being held at the bar. As out of towners we thought it would be fun to join in and we were right. We had a perfect time, had a great time with the staff and other patrons and really enjoyed ourselves. Great true neighborhood bar where you can get smashed and the bartender can get smashed and everyone has a great night. Skip the tourist spots and meet some people that live here.
author: Bobby H.

description: Good bar with a pretty good vibe on Columbus. Only stopped for one beer on a bar crawl down the road. A few screens for sport and some good people watching if you sit at the window
author: Andrew F.

description: The bar tender was homophobic and rude. I would strongly recommend not going to this bar. I was quite surprised by this based on some of the other reviews.
author: Luke R.

description:
Old school bar showing its age, but still an A-OK place for a beer or cocktail. We've been here a couple times, and it appears La Rocca attracts mostly locals, with a few tourists coming through.  Locals and bartender (Sil has served us every visit) have always been pleasant . . .

Cheers!
Rich
author: Rich S.

description: Bartender friendly a good stop after Lombard street. Try the local brews. Gives me my Wisconsin small town vibe.
author: Jessica R.

description:
I would stand by the following statement:  "Sil is either the best bartender in SF, or one of the best bartenders in SF."  I have never had a bad time here.  Whatever else you could say about this bar, the bartender IS this bar for much of the clientele.  Certainly is for me.  I've lived in SF for a few years.  I came here early, but not often.  I'm now realizing how good a spot this is.

This is an old school kinda place.  Good old North Beach.  A lot of the folks around are from the neighborhood.  I love coming to a place like this and seeing people who know each other.  SF is great for that.  This place should be a must for the type who want to hang out and drink and watch some good games in North Beach.  I've met some SUPER cool people here.  

If you're down soaking up the SF tourist-culture near Fisherman's Wharf, do yourself a favor and take the trek up through North Beach.  Lock, and get-Loaded.  You start on this end of Columbus, and move up.  Lots of cool spots along the way.  And, you can get some great food after soaking up the fun at La Rocca's.
author: Adam S.

description: Stopped in here randomly with my boyfriend looking for a bathroom and We decided to have a couple beeers. And I'm so glad we did because SYL was AWESOME! I've worked in the service industry for years and let me tell you that he is the main reason we will be back! Not only did we get drinks but we got a show as well! He had us laughing the whole time! Thank you syl for your amazing customer service skills!
author: Jamie R.

description: Mellow spot on Saturday afternoon. German bartender lady was very nice and made the atmosphere very enjoyable. Good time!
author: Kevin S.

description: You want a super old-school, no-frills dive? You've found it. Old photos and street signs plaster the walls. Oldies crank out of the dated jukebox. And, classic drinks come out from behind the bar, such as Irish coffee. Drinks are cheap. Think 2 draft beers, a whiskey on the rocks, and a gin and tonic for $22. There's no food. The chairs are sticky. And, the clientele drink for hours. Welcome home. You'll thank me later.
author: Danny C.

description: Went to la Roccas corner after the Columba's day parade for the free Irish coffees and transgender bathrooms. The most helpful and handsome bartender was behind the bar. Even though he wasn't from the city I'll definitely be back to see him!
author: Paul M.

description:
Bar hoping in SF this was one of my favorite bars because it has a dove-bar home feel like Sacramento (where I'm from). Paul was my bartender who is a character and isn't shy about starting a conversation. Some businesses in the big cities forget about the hospitality and the care for the customer's experience. Don't be shy when you tip these guys! 

The bar is kind of small, I could only imagine how crowded it can quickly get on a busy night. A pool table would be awesome at this bar if they had room for it.
author: LJ V.

description:
Last weekend my boyfriend and I wandered in here with pretty low expectations. 
We had caught a ride over to this side of town hoping to meet up with a friend, but ended up wandering around deserted streets lined with closed bars and restaurants. 
After a few minutes of walking, off in the distance we saw neon signs beckoning us in. We desperately made our way inside, glad to see signs of life. 
After sitting down it was pretty obvious this is a local hangout, but I disagree with what another yelper said, "tourists stay away". We felt totally welcome and ended up staying here most of our nightly strictly because of Paul. Paul really made our whole experience, he's hilarious. 
I wish I could remember what he put in the shots we had, they were amazing...
author: Brianna H.

description:
Walking by this corner bar, I noticed the Giants game on the TV and peered into the window to check out the score and continued on my way.  I then hear someone calling me.  Turned around and saw that it was Ron aka "Sil", a classmate at Salesian since kindergarten, who I haven't seen in over 20 years. He invited me in for a drink.

Though I've walked by many times, this was my first venture into this neighborhood bar.  LaRocca's is a true classic old-school neighborhood watering hole.  I come to find out that Sil is a bartender here, but was here watching the Giants game this evening on his off-night.  The bartender got my drink order and Sil and I chatted about old times.  The bar patrons appeared to be neighborhood regulars.  We along with the bartender talked about the action on the screen.  The bar has long tables and tables along the windows that face out to the busy Columbus Ave, great for people watching and seeing the cable cars rumbling by. 

This is not your hot, vibrant bar, but a classic neighborhood bar were "Hi Norm" comes to mind.
author: Al L.

description: We heard this was a great place for Irish Coffee. Our bartender Paul was great fun and gave us lots of tips for places to visit, restaurants, etc.
author: Traci R.

description: Came for a weekend trip to the city and came across this little bar. Great atmosphere and good old school rock music.  The staff are very friendly and drinks are reasonable.. Great location with window seating.
author: Petra F.

description: My favorite bar in SF. Been going here for over 15yrs. Bartenders are cool. Drinks are good. Prices are fair. Old school bar.
author: Rhodes L.

description:
It smells bad. A STRONG combo of mold and urine. 
I used to like this place and the people are basically friendly but the odor is really unbearable.
They need to hire professionals to deep deep deep clean the place.
author: M. M.

description: this place rocks. the bartender, mack, gave us 2 free drinks for our first visit. drinks were good, classic dive bar atmosphere. definitely coming back!!!!
author: Mackenzie M.

description:
This is It! 

I have seen that sign many times as I've walked by La Rocca's Corner. Maybe it's a North Beach institution? I've also been told that it was DiMaggio's old bar, the site of a mob hit, and a scene in a Bond movie.

What La Rocca's is to me is a friendly and low-key neighbourhood bar that is good for a drink and maybe a story. Mine involves a drink with my parents at this cozy dive bar, with memories of Milwaukee and good times gone by and newly created.
author: Eric B.

description: Cool place - been around since the 1920's so lots of history and plenty regulars who will be happy to share stories or just look around at the pictures.  Jukebox has mostly oldies and classic rock, our kind of music.  8-10 drafts? including a cider.
author: Gloria H.

description: If you like drinking without pretension, this is the place. My brother and I stumbled across this place on the walk back to the financial district after a visit to the Buena Vista.  We rolled in at 1130am on 12/29/2016.  We ordered two shots and two beers.  The bartender immediately took care of us and joined us for our first shot.  There were only four other patrons at the bar but they immediately joined us in to the conversation and made us feel at home.  Only ten minutes later, one of the patrons bought us a round of shots.  Great down to earth people that made us welcome from the beginning.  Make no mistake, this is not a free wifi look at me millenial watering hole.  This is a no wifi, no food, drinking establishment.  People go here for great conversation, great service, and to take a break in a hectic beautiful city.  It makes it even better the prices are totally reasonable too.  Please stop here for a cocktail and get a different look at San Francisco.  I will definitely be back.  This place is an institution and a great example of what San Francisco used to be and still is.
author: Joshua R.

description:
The bartender does not like young people at his bar and basically ignored everyone under 30 to serve older people even if they walked in afterwards. 

Ended up walking out of this bar without having been said hello to.
author: Minks M.

description:
My girlfriends and I (literally) stumbled into La Rocca's on accident, but stayed for hours and hours, only to come back the next day and do the same. There were a few bartenders who were all extremely kind and patient with us. We were there for a bachelorette party weekend, so I'm sure we were driving everyone nuts... Paul took such good care of us all night, and honestly deserves a gold medal for all of his help and compassion!
We Love La Rocca's! Thanks, PAUL!
author: Elyse J.

description: "The Fri - Sun day shift bartendar Syl is the best!" If every local bar could clone him & hire him they should! His quick-witted humor was right up our alley. He is also sweet, super friendly, quick & accurate w/the drinks, and not to be missed if you have a choice of the many many bars/pubs in the area. We live in the East Bay & had a whole day to walk around North Beach. We stopped in cuz he had a Warrior shirt on & it was the best place we popped into by far. We'll definitely be back. (The regular patrons were super friendly too - what a gem of a little whole in the wall.) Thanks for the laughs and GREAT time!!
author: Izzie D.

description:
Pretty divey which I like, so we stopped in (5 of us) and on a sunday night we made up half of the patrons.  Place was nothing special. A wee bit stinky, but I was sitting at the end of the bar closer to the restroom ... I guess I could have moved but still... Drinks were pricey ($5 for an O'Doul's punishes the DD lol).  Other patrons were a bit out of order - not a big deal until the bartender couldn't handle a little noise from my buddy (who was telling/reenacting a story about a monkey - yes - monkey calls were involved - and they were rather authentic sounding).  
It wasnt so horrible - after all, this is a bar, not a restaurant or a library.  If it annoyed you - make a joke or be polite at your place of business.  Mr. Bartender, you seem like a nice enough guy but posing threats, even in jest to your paying, drinking customers because you are annoyed is not nice.  Really put off by the remarks about Mexicans and middle easterners :-( that came out of nowhere.  

Anyway, try this place if you like- not a bad spot but not a destination either. Just do not tell any stories with monkeys.
author: J A.

description: Divey and I love it. My son and I rented bikes on the wharf and rode around the city for an afternoon. It was a perfect day, we worked up some sweat and enjoyed my favorite big city in the world. Afterwards we had some time to kill so we walked around and looked for a cool place to intake some carbs. A trip through Trader Joe's for some water and chocolate bars lead us further inland and right to La Rocca's Corner for a couple of pints while the afternoon turned into evening. The locals were talking crap about the 49ers and all the 2014 season would hold for them. I just sat back and enjoyed the show, and the wonderful ambience of a old school corner bar.
author: David P.

description: I used to like having a few beers at La Rocca's when I was in the neighborhood. I coulda sworn the PBR drafts were like $2 a year ago but now they're $5, seriously? $5 for a PBR? Thanks, Johnny. It was great while it lasted.
author: Stephen W.

description: yea, it's a dive bar, but not quite in that charming way, pretty grimey, some rough characters in here.  good for surly locals, tourists stay away, most of the regulars were over 60 from looks of it.  bartender seemed friendly enough just some of the others in the crowd i wasn't so sure of
author: Jeff H.

description: Great hole in the wall bar! I walked in late one night when visiting San Francisco for business. I was with my fiancée and our friend and we were meeting with at least other 2 people. We passed up a few bars and none had any seating available. We strolled into this place, and had a great time!
author: Maria J.

description:
This little bar is awesome!

When you order a $6 Jack/Coke they mean BUSINESS! :)

It's a great place to hang out whilst waiting for a show at the Cobbs comedy club. 

I will definitely come back next time I'm going to Cobbs.
author: Kari M.

description: Great place& cheap drinks, took me forever to reach $10 haha. PBR!  Bartender was friendly and funny.
author: Andy H.

description:
This is a nice, low-key place to stop for a drink if you're in North Beach. Forget the hustle and bustle of all the other spots! This place is the shit! Nobody talks to you (ie "bothers" you) and the drinks are cheap. It's centrally located, too. 

My only complaint about this place is that the Yankees knocked the Angels out of the playoffs while I was here. That's bad juju. Otherwise, this place would get four stars!
author: Laila P.

description:
Rock'n La Rocca's

The first clue on the Yelp Drink & Hunt Event led us to this little corner stop bar. Nice little joint, though the tenders could have been a bit more cooperative, as they acted if they had no idea that there was an Elite event taking place that evening. At least they make a decent Ol'fashion. We found our next clue in the back of the bar. The  space seemed pretty chill, I might stop back here for a few one of these nights. But no time to lollygag, we got the clue, deciphered it, took our shots, and were off to the next location.
author: Andrew D.

description:
We love La Rocca's! 

The bartenders are each fascinating characters (Sil is my sober-hero!) and if you dig the old-man bars, there are a minimum of three hanging on to the end of the bar at all times. 

As a manageable sized sports-bar (there are no jock-y type guys hanging out here, however), it's got a few TV's, which my boyfriend loves. The owner, bartender and their crew are baseball fans and my boyfriend felt right at home when the owner gave champagne to the crowd when the Giants won the World Series. As an academic study-hall, La Rocca's got lots of light and great big tables on which I can spread out my French homework. This may seem like a dumb thing to appreciate, but you just try studying in a bar that has no ground-level tables and chairs and zero natural light!

I give La Rocca's only 4 stars because it fails in an essential element. It's not that the mixed drinks can be dinky, because their manhattans can be terrific (and I'm the pickiest of the picky). No. More importantly, the women's bathroom is revolting. There are things in there that no woman should ever have to see or touch. Come on guys, peek in there every so often and give it a good scrub down. How about some paint and is a decent mirror and formal soap dispenser that doesn't fall off the ancient sink so big of a deal? Sometimes I just don't have the stomach to use that bathroom and have to run up the street to my boyfriend's apartment before I pee my pants.
author: Artemis A.

description:
La Rocca's Corner is a classic neighborhood hangout in North Beach.  Opened over 80 years ago, this bar is a great place to rub elbows with friendly locals, visiting tourists (the cable car runs past La Rocca's headed towards the Wharf).  Owners Mike Roddy and Marty Coyne have treated the La Rocca's legacy with respect. 

Come down and hang with some great bartenders, almost all of them Native San Franciscans. Talk sports, have a cocktail or two, watch the world pass by.  

I posted a video about my recent trip to La Rocca's Corner.  Check it out at  http://bit.ly/aQ8vkr
author: Dennis C.

description: Jonny the owner is the man!! Super mellow atmosphere during the daylight hours and always something good to watch on one of the many TVs
author: Ian P.

description:
North Beach sports bar, emphasis on North Beach. The cappucinos are real North Beach cappucinos. The beer selection is the usual semi-eclectic, half dozen regional brews and imported taps. The decor is real old-man-bar stuff like Tug of War posters and photos signed by Willie Brown. 

I used to feel guilty heading to a dark bar at 9 AM on a sunny Fall SF Saturday to watch my beloved Spartans. But LaRocca's Corner is one of the unofficial homes of the Michigan State University Bay Area Alumni Club (Kezar Pub is another). For football they have a 42" plasma HD with all the games (mostly Big Ten) and bartenders who actually know how all the equipment works. And sound's not a problem since it's only busy if the alumni group is there. 

La Rocca's bright sunny windows, great neighborhood food, and views of passing cable cars mean you can have the best of both worlds: Get your college football fix and a cappucino and walk out with a W and still have the rest of the day to enjoy the city.
author: Brandon R.

description:
This bar is a pretty nice find near North Beach. A quiet little spot that is conveniently located along the way up the hill from Fisherman's Wharf to North Beach, the decor is laid back and kind of an old school drinking hall.

The 7&7s I ordered were heavily poured, and affordable to boot. The bartender who poured them was friendly and attentive, he chatted us up about various things, his Catholic upbringing and Catholic girls chief among them. Go figure.

The juke box was loaded with some great tunes, and that counts for a lot. My date and I were entertained by an older couple who decided to make use of the space that evening for an impromptu dance number. On that note, the bar's spacing is a little awkward, but the bar itself provides great seating.

The bath rooms were clean, albeit tagged up in just about every corner. Beware the cabbie who sneaks in every night and drops bombs. You don't wanna wander in after him, seriously.
author: Wes T.

description:
A triangular room with windows along the hypotenuse makes for a sunlight rich environment.  La Rocca bills itself as a place where "The tourists meet the locals".  A lot of places make this claim....La Rocca's is the only one I know of that actually delivers on it.

Regulars usually sit towards the entrance at the corner of Columbus & Chestnut.  Feel free to join in, but be ready to scoot down if the locals want to make room for another regular.  Well placed TV's and low-volume music help foster a sports-and-conversation friendly environment.

The crowd consists of local retirees mixed with tourists.  For reasons unbeknown to myself, something about La Rocca seems to elicit frequent conversations between the two groups.  Both locals and the bartender are happy to give directions, advice, or tips on where to eat.  Aging but well preserved wood covers the place, and an interesting collection of local photos graces the walls.

I love this place.  It's humble, it's friendly, and it's got local flair.  And for all practical purposes, I can't think of any other reason for a local to walk  this far up Columbus Street.
author: Mike W.

description: My friends and I had the best time here our first night in San Fran!  We had been down by the wharf getting Irish Coffees, and decided to walk around. On a whim, we saw this bar, and decided to go in and get a beer.  Before we knew it, several hours had passed, and we were hanging out with the owner after hours, having great conversation, and drinking way too much.  Good times! or at least I think.....
author: Red F.

description: Came here all the time when I lived in North Beach. Absolutely love the bartender - super nice guy, and makes great drinks. Extremely good prices. Little spot on the corner, and a very chill atmosphere.
author: Mia D.

description: Came here after Cobb's on a Thursday night and it wasn't crowded at all. We had about 20 people in our group so it was nice to be able to take over the bar without causing people to hate us. The bartender was great and poured some pretty stiff drinks for us. I'd definitely come back again.
author: Lauren D.

description: Laid-back, old-school vibe to the place.  The bartenders are the right amount of sarcastic and friendly.  The jukebox makes me happy as well.
author: David P.

description: Small Bar - GREAT service.  Hard to find a dive bar that will go the extra mile, and these guys do.
author: James W.

description:
Most people: Drinks, football on TV, conversation with the barkeep about how/when/if the 49ers will ever turn things around while watching the cable cars roll by.

Me: Espresso, Sunday paper, headphones with EDM to drown out the football while watching the cable cars roll by.

All: A fine way to experience an eight decade North Beach institution.
author: Jason B.

description: The bartender here was too drunk to attend to his duties, and was outright rude to some of his customers who were trying to place orders.  His shouting at the patrons  to leave the bar at the end of the night really killed the experience here, and I'd never visit this bar again.
author: Dan D.

description:
The B&C almost lost her lunch and all dignity for my family when I told her that a family member actually was "in the know" about some shady dealings "in the day" when a certain young union organizer was stuffed into the trunk of a waiting '62 Caddy in front of La Rocca's.  Yup, cement shoes were fitted, applied and walking papers were given.

Yes, family dinners in NB with my grandparents and great uncle/aunt were always a time to learn of stories of a caliber years beyond my comprehension.

This place has been around longer than alcohol itself.  The bar is smallish but with a bunch of character.  We burned and hour before some friends showed for the Jeff Ross show at Cobb's.  All friendly, all good.

I love and miss my old hood, and no, not because I miss killing people.

:)
author: Johnny L.

description:
Imagine drinking yourself into infancy and observing this place on a busy Saturday night.  All of these fun friendly people have drinks and they're not sharing.  But the first and foremost observation is the noise.  You can reach out and touch this wall of noise buzzing in your face like moths who just found a ninety-watt light bulb.  The dissonance is a huge red punch to the ear drums and it suffocates the senses, if only temporarily.
 
The bar is lit by a golden yellow light and, underneath its lambency, the SFGG Rugby Club is huddled together, sploshing beer about and howling for one another's approval.  A bright neon light shines from the window, lighting up the smokers outside on the sidewalk.  They look like bead-covered blobs through the rain-spotted windows.  The television's on up above, but no one is watching.  There's a juke box in here, but I can't hear it.  The beatific faces rush by laughing and yelling like they just discovered a new galaxy.  Someone brushes by me in the rush of things.  I try to look over at the person.  I overcompensate and find myself looking up at the fan.  I then attempt to look back and the person is just another blur laughing with a bigger louder blur.  The chatter grows as voices compete with other voices in order to be heard over the other louder voices.  The bartenders keep the tables clear of glasses, condensation, crumbs, spills ... and they keep the cups of merriment full to the brim.  
 
I see a girl sitting on a barstool from across the bar.  From my point of view, she looks bewildered.. confused.. uncertain.  I wade across the room full of noise and reach her, tapping her shoulder in an affable manner.  She turns around and looks at me with a peculiar glance.  I totally forget what I was going to say to her.  I am entangled in the surrounding buzz.  My thoughts drift about in the commotion.  She is saying something up at me in a humorous tone that I can't decipher.  I laugh and nod as I float away against the current of patrons bellying up to the bar.  There are so many conversations, so many drink options, so many people possibilities - I am overwhelmed in an instant.  I once again find myself sitting calmly against the window with another full pint in my hand.  I am back to square one, whatever or wherever that is.
author: Kenny R.

description: Mike roddy and the boys know how to make you feel welcome.  Found this place 15 years ago in a rugby crawl.   Always stay at Columbus inn down the street so I can start and end my night here and walk back.   Cheers mates!   Oh, try the fernet...
author: Davey J.

description: Conveniently near Cobb's for a pre-game beer!
author: Maximillian M.

description: Fantastic Local Watering Hole. These guys couldn't be nicer, more real or treat you better. Had a great time here. Met the owner. Fantastic people great dive bar ambience. Low price, strong pour! Can't wait to go back and have a drink with the boys! This place was home away from home in San Fran.
author: James M.

description: Great place to come grab a drink and hangout. The place seemed to be packed with regulars who didn't mind sharing their conversation with anybody else who happened to be in the bar. The friendly atmosphere extended to the employees as well, who were friendly and easy-going. The place is extremely laid back, which makes it a great place to relax with a drink. As an added bonus, they've got TVs up for the games
author: Taylor C.

description:
STAY AWAY!!!
If I could give this place zero stars, I most definitely would. It is not deserving of even an inkling of a star.
Myself and some friends met my boyfriend there after a commercial shoot. (No, we are not models or actors...my friend's brother was the director so he graciously let us be in it.)
Anyhoo, Jeff didn't feel like hanging out in the cold for the whole thing, so he headed down Chestnut to the nearest bar: La Rocca's.
When we got there, there were maybe six people in the bar, not including my bf or the bartender, all of whom were dudes who clearly were not used to interacting with women on any level.
When we ordered beers, the bartender thought we were all on the same tab, but we weren't so he proceeded to tell us the bill was "all fucked up".
When he figured out who owed what, my friend asked if there were any drink specials since her beer was a little expensive. The bartender replied with, "Five bucks is expensive? Where the fuck are you from? If you want cheaper beers, you should probably just fucking drink at home." 
Not that five bucks is terribly expensive, but there are many, MANY (way cooler) bars in the city, with cheaper drink prices. His hostile response was a little shocking and totally douchey. 
We all agreed no tip was in order and when he picked up our credit card slip said, "Wow. Thanks." Sorry, fucktard, but you act like a dick to customers, you're gonna get treated like one. 
I know this is a total tourist trap of a bar, so we really had no business being in there, but Jesus, if I was a tourist and got that kind of abuse, it would leave a shitty taste in my mouth about SF for sure. It left one in mine. The only way I would ever step foot in this dump again is to purposely not tip this asshole.
Too bad, because according to my bf, about ten minutes before we got there a really cool older bartender was working who hooked him up with shots. Sorry, old dude, but that douchebag that took over for you tonight is a real stain on your establishment.
Totally unappealing on EVERY level.
author: Susie D.

description:
I recently have created my own little "Team in Training" for a very important upcoming event called "Drues Nite Lite DYL". I am traveling all the way to Seattle to participate and I hear my competition is fierce.  My many coaches are supporting me in getting into prime shape for this upcoming event. Lots of people are counting on me to represent San Francisco and not let anyone down. I know I cannot, under any circumstances, be the first one to puke in a gutter and pass out in a drunken stupor on the seemingly huge bar crawl that will be taking place next week. 

So, lately when I leave a party to "go home" my coaches really push me to have just one more drink, or two, before I give up! Such was the case this last Thursday when on the way home from a beer filled evening at Kennedys there was the "Irish Coffee" sign staring out at us from La Roccas. This was an opportunity not just to drink but to mix those alcohols, thus strengthening my digestive system further. 

I have been into this little corner bar many times. It is actually a great place to train. The shape is this weird corner building with an island in the middle, thus making it hard to navigate while sober, especially when it gets a little crowded with the mix of locals and tourists it attracts, so to navigate it drunk is quite a challenge indeed. This helps with the agility I will be needing. 

They have a nice selection of alcoholic beverages, and the bartenders do a decent job of pouring drinks that are not weak and do not charge what you would expect for the area. This place isn't quite a dive, not exactly a neighborhood bar, not a tourist spot and definitely isn't your typical North Beach night spot either. It is just an older, smaller worn in place to get your drink on and maybe catch some sports on one of their strategically placed TVs. 

If only they would stop using canned whipped cream in their Irish Coffee, I would train here more often and award them more stars.
author: Drue C.

description:
While there are many aleholes to choose from in North Beach, this is one of my favorites.

Faint odor of urine and bleach? Check!
Men's room the size of a U-Boat potty? Check!
Bartenders that drink with you? Check!
Wedding photos of JFK and Jackie? Check!
Ex-cop looking Irish bartender with a name like Big Mike? Check!
Jukebox containing everything from Sam Cooke to the Pogues? Check!

Lose yourself for an hour or a lifetime, come on down and drink with dignity!
author: Mack N.

description:
Just under "since 1922" is a sign, "where tourists meet the locals", more hopeful thinking than reality.  Surveying the crowd of drunks, not so drunks, foxy 40-year-olds, and bicycle messengers, you would be hard-pressed to find a tourist.

It's the kind of joint where the bartender uses "ergo" a lot to make a point, most of the old white men wear baseball caps hood forward thank you, fleece is in, your change is ten dollars they slap a ten on the counter, and the bartender who has been at it long enough pinpoint the top of the glass like a laser deliberately counts to ten and leaves the extra in a strainer-topped glass for you to pour  a second round for yourself.

The wood here is older than your grandmother, but they still carry the good stuff.
author: Gil S.

description:
I came her last night after being in the Mission for a few hours.  We showed up around 11pm and hoped for some decent drinks and fun atmosphere.  Now I came with a girlfriend because he friend was moving, so it was a going away party. 

So now I will review.  The service was slow and the drinks were really Tiny, I used to work in a restaurant and I remember when our manager bought glasses that looked the same as the old ones but were shaped a little differently so that there was less liquor.  Now my drink was not all coke, but definitely not as much Jack as I usually get.  

The atmosphere would have been nice if I wanted to come and chill with a few friends and have a drink.  It's definitely a bar you start with, not end on.  It would be a good place to grab a drink before a show although $6 in a bar for the same size drink you get at the show for $8 kinda erked me.  

I'm sure it's a good dive bar, just not my steez.  I like to dance and there was not going to be any dancing there last night or any other.  But maybe I'll try it again some day because it was a Tuesday night.
author: Megan L.

description: I was having fun when I first sat down in this friendly environment.  That is until the bartender began using derogatory words to describe gay people.  After explaining to him that his language was insensitive and offensive, especially considering the high population of gays in SF AND the recent gay teen bullying tragedies, he continued.  He even rang the "last call" bell, shouting "LAST CALL, FAGGOTS!" I left after this.  So, if you are gay or just support the GLBT community, I would not recommend going to La Rocca's Corner.
author: Allysyn O.

description:
Great little corner dive bar.

Interesting cast of characters - always makes for some fun.

Strong pours and good prices.

Very small so get ready to get "intimate" with your neighbor.
author: Nicole Rynee B.

description:
Friend of mine was in town this weekend, and as a prior Russian Hill resident, he knew exactly where his old SF buddies should meet him to get drunk.

I don't mean just a casual get together and catch up. I mean get all Tom Waits and stumble around town messed up.

Funny thing was, I totally didn't remember ever coming to this bar before. However, after two beers and some whiskey it hit me like an angry alcoholic father... I've definitely been here several times.. and it always ends crazy.

Oh, and attention Bella, there is a poster signed by Willie Brown in the men's bathroom. I didn't understand what it meant, and have no idea if it's real, but I thought you might appreciate it.
author: Rhett G.

description: Your standard corner bar.  We went in here to get some Fernet shots, but didn't stick around too long to really get a feel for the place.  Right across the road is the International Sports Club; I prefer that place for no good reason other than I like that place.
author: Paolo D.

description:
Just awful. The sign outside reads, "Where locals meet tourists". How right they are, as local a-holes from the neighborhood rub shoulders with slack-jawed yokels from god-knows-where.

Any bar that immediately cranks the jukebox to deafening volume as soon as a reggae song comes on is 'chock full o' douche'. 

Any bar where 90% of the guys are significantly shorter than their girlfriends is 'chock full o' douche'. 

Any bar in which there are overly competitive frat guys surrounding the bar, playing dice for shots and shouting at some pledge on the phone about how they're gonna totally make some guy do a 'ton of kegstands' when he gets back, just might be 'chock full o' douche'.
author: Andrew L.

description:
When you stop in an Irish bar for an Irish Coffee, you expect a good Irish Coffee. Sadly, La Rocca's does not deliver. I can't put my finger on what exactly is wrong, but it's just not as smooth as one would hope.

La Rocca's does, however, have a good atmosphere, and when you are interested in concentrating on your company and the intimate discussions you're having, this is an excellent location for such. Negotiating the comfortable but haphazard seating arrangement might be another issue entirely.
author: Paul B.

description:
I have always liked this bar (for its $2 PBR) because it's really chill and I have a soft-spot for old-man bars, but last week I heard both bartenders saying about the neighborhood crime "if you're brown, get out of town".  When I asked him to repeat what he said the bartender (who is a short fat bald headed man who looks like Curly from the Three Stooges...without the humor) stuttered, "Oh,  I mean, um, what I meant to say if someone wants to cause trouble they shouldn't be here."  And then he digressed, "This is North Beach, not Bayview or hip-hop land,,,)." 

Curly is a racist and so is the other bartender (brown hair, dark mustache, old man) for agreeing with him.

Lame Rocca's, lame.  I guess I'll find my cheap beer elsewhere, at least when Curly and the guy with the molesterstache are working.
author: Dedadean H.

description:
Friendly tavern in North Beach to hang out at before checking out a show at Cobb's Comedy Club, Bimbo's 365, or simply for a night out on the town!

Pros: Good mix of locals and tourists, bartenders are generally friendly - didn't give us too many dirty looks when our visiting guest asked for a drink on draft that was obviously limited to the New England area....close to a lot of other good bars and restaurants...

Cons: Wish it was closer to the Bart or my apartment down in Burlingame!
author: Kimberly K.

description:
I spent too much of my life there so I quit drinking and now stroll past and think fondly of the many good memories. When my old SF friends come back to the city we often start or end the evening at LaRocca's.  

Except when Bimbo's and Cobb's have star headliners parking in this part of North Beach isn't too bad especially if you are willing to climb a few blocks to retrieve your car. But why drink and drive when the 30 Stockton is right outside or you can grab a cab before the competition really gets tough in the middle of NB?  The place can get busy when there are big  North Beach events, the local nightclubs have a big name performer, or there is a big sporting events.

Great jukebox, wide selection of beers, usually an interesting mix of people, and I like every one of the bartenders.  Tourists comprise a very small percentage of patrons and don't spend nearly the amount of time that the locals do.  This is a great place for a drinking session with your buddies.  

Though LaRocca's isn't for every one, particularly people who don't understand proper bar ettiquette and abuse the word douche.  One Yelp review that cites the bartender kept dropping the F bomb is something I've never seen anything close to but  certainly isn't outside the parameters of possibilities.  In that case the Yelper states that three entered, ordered three drinks gave the bartender a card and then told him they wanted to pay individually.  I'm not sure what is weaker: Not telling the bartender that the first card was for one drink, or being too damned cheap to buy your friends a drink? 

For the literate folks out there the place during most hours is more like "The Tender Bar" and less like "Cheers". Those times LaRocca's is hosting a reunion party, showing ballgames for  the Wisconsin Badgers SF alumni, or other local televised sporting events the place loses some of its dark charm.   The odd shape of the place creates a great flow that makes the place feel comfortable.

Best Recent Moment at Larocca's: Giants are two outs away from winning the World Series when a 30 Stockton pulls into the bus stop.  Bus driver opens the front door and asks what is going on? and is told  "We're about to win the World Series.  Except for two people on the 1/5 full bus everyone takes a position at the bus length of windows on the right side of the bus to watch BWilson close out Texas. Victory was sealed and big smiles and cheering in the bus as it pulled away while LaRocca's became a Champage drenching lovefest .
author: Marc B.

description: I give this bar 5 stars because it is MY KIND OF BAR!  it is filled with local city people, which I am.  A few tourists come in, and if you are an open minded and politically incorrect tourist, this is the place for you.  There is no place for sensitivlty training here.  There is usually more men than women...in fact I am usually one of he few women that frequent this place.  I know the owners, the bartenders, and the regulars so I feel at home.  If you have a sharp tongue, like to throw a few caps and take a few this is the place for you!
author: Beckster B.

description: This is a local hangout, mainly North Beach residents. Cross-towners and young transplants need not apply. I watched every World Series game here for the shear atmosphere. I wasn't looking for a big crowded sports bar. I wanted to look at the expressions on the faces of locals who grew up loving the Giants. Although I am an Indians fan, La Rocca's made the World Series worth watching. Thanks to everyone at La Rocca's for making it so memorable and an extra thanks to Sil and Marty for the extra shot of Fernet.
author: Richard J.

description:
Good:
- shows all the big football games (real football that is)
- not too crowded (which is good if you want somewhere to sit while watching the above mentioned games)
- the local white collar alcoholics hang out here which gives the place a somewhat miserable but cozy feeling
- not too pricey even though it's located on the tourists' main avenue
- even though they don't serve food themselves they are ok with you bringing over food from the taqueria next door and sometimes they will even take your order for you and run over and get your food while you're watching your game (now that is good service!)

Not so good:
- sometimes the waiters can be a little slow and lazy
- a tornado of flies always reside in the middle of the room....they don't really bother you as they stick to their spot in the middle of the room, but a tornado of flies is always a tornado of flies
- the TV-screen could be bigger

Not sure if it's good or not:
- one of the waiters (short one with long hair in a pony tail) can sometimes get drunk while off his shift and start harassing his co-workers and guests (it makes for a good show since he seems to be kind of harmless)
author: Pastor Z.

description: Been twice, beers are never as cold as I'd like and the vibe has been tired and weary. Not my favorite place, but it's convenient right off the cable car line.
author: Kellee K.

description: Been here a few times before/after shows at Bimbo's/Cobbs.  Everything you want from a dive.  Good down to earth people with a healthy amount of snark. Both at the the bar and behind it.  Heavy handed pours.
author: Kevin F.

description: It's clear that this bar has been a fixture in the neighborhood for a long time and you can feel the character when you enter it.  It's a nice place to catch up with the locals, but until recently it wasn't a great spot for younger crowds.  However, I stumbled in randomly on a Tuesday night to discover the launch of 'Beer Wars' every 2nd Tuesday of the month.  Teams of co-eds were competing in games from beer pong to flip cup while listening to a newly added sound system.  When I asked one of the cute girls near me why they were there they told me that the winning team gets their bar tab comp'd at the end of the night and the bartenders let them dance on the bar and do body shots.  Nice!
author: draven t.

description: On our honeymoon and on a sunny September afternoon after walking up to, and down from, Coit Tower my wife and I stumbled upon La Rocca's and headed in for a much needed drink. The place was mostly empty except for (i'm guessing) a handful of regulars. We grabbed a seat near the window and I moseyed up to the bar and ordered a couple of drinks. I can"t remember the bartenters name but he had a very graveley voice and was beyond friendly. He asked me my and wifes name and where we were from and what bought us in. Told him our story and he congradulated us on our marriage and got us our drinks. It is a perfect place to relax and watch the world go by. After about 3 drinks each we went to square up and the bartender told us to give him $5 and that he's giving us the drinks as a wedding gift. He WOULD NOT take more than the five no matter how hard I tried. Great place, great location and fantastic staff. It is a real great memory for both me and my wife. We were left alone to talk and it was a nice afternoon. Loses one star because of the teeny washrooms, which were'nt super dirty, but not real clean either.
author: T M.

description: Went caroling on Sunday afternoon.  The bartender made great drink and was super nice.  Great people.  Tip them well!
author: Ian M.

description:
i like this place.  i like the drunk bartender.  he reminds me of a guy i used to work with.  i like the owner who is always nice to my girlfriend.  i like the fact all the tv's are facing the bartenders so they can watch the giants or 49er's while they work.  i like the music which can be loud at times.  i like the fact that every time i walk in this place i end up talking to someone who can be totally insane.  la roccas's is a fun local sf pub.  if you want to hear old stories of north beach and how things used to be, then stop in at la roccas.  it's one of the best bars in sf!

i dropped a star for their really small bathroom.  damn, was that made for a midget?
author: T D.

description: I've seen a couple Badger games here, and while it's a little small and out of the way for me, it's a great little spot to hunker down on a Saturday afternoon. There's something about North Beach on a weekend that's really nice and almost magical. But it's nice, with decent beers on tap, sunlight pouring in, and a really friendly staff waiting on you. And we bring in a bunch of Badger fans, they serve us complementary sausages, which makes them top notch in my book.
author: Michael E.

description: a fun fun fun place to tip a few before supping at any given NB trattoria. I'm used to the smell of stale beer so all is good. happiness is finding a well-poured drink without spending tons of $$$
author: Prima D.

description: I just returned from 5 months in Ireland and was expecting not to find any decent pub-like atmosphere in north beach. Wrong. I love La Rocca's. I can always hear my friends talking, they have pear cider, and I can people watch from the window stools. It's a block from my apt and I wish it were my living room.
author: Julie C.

description: great place strong drinks and a great atmosphere i give it a thumbs up but please stay away from the taqueria next door really sucks
author: Danny T.

description: Great place to hang comfortably, people watch, catch some local history / gossip.  Delicious pear cider there, love that stuff.  Can order grub from the place next door, they'll bring it on over.  I like to stop over before and after a show at Cobb's Comedy Club a few steps away.
author: Sheila G.

description: Standard tavern. Cheap drinks, nice out-of-the-way location. Beware roving bands of Sacred Heart alums prone to coke-induced random violence.
author: Megan W.

description: Everytime I come to La Rocca's, the night (or day) gets really interesting. I love this place because everyone is really nice and keeps their eye on the prize: to get drunk. I brought a couple of my friends and gave them the bartender's specialty (my personal favorite)- its basically tequila and espresso. That will get you moving if your feeling unmotivated. These guys know their stuff- ask them about the history of Fernet and they'll give you the story. Great spot, glad its in my neighborhood.
author: J.C. H.

description: A fun way to start off the evening....Not too many people, fantastic, friendly bartenders who make some great concoctions.  I met a group of friends here to kick off the evening and it was perfect!  I think at some point Phil Collins was played on the juke box, but that just adds to the flair.  Big windows for people watching and being watched, easy access to Bimbo's for pre/post show or company Christmas party; whatever your event may be.
author: ellyk E.

description: Great bar!  Corner spot perfect for people-watching, great jukebox that they'll just pump $$$ into and let you choose, beers galore, and rugby on t.v.  Dude, it's the most ruthless sport EVER!  Metal screw-ins, no pads, catching AND kicking... I hope they have a US-NZ Gridiron so our NFL primadonas can get a taste of real hits and possibly knock their egos down a bit. A huge plus-The mex place next door will deliver right to your barstool!  Nice : )
author: Tara G.

description: Been here all of three times, but each time was a good time.  Sports/Rugby bar, well priced drinks, great jukebox, but it tends to get VERY crowded and VERY loud. Lots of fun memorabila on the walls, the bartenders are nice and heavy handed with the liquor so go on, get drunk and enjoy.
author: Catherine K.

description: This place is known for its strong drinks and strange cast of regulars. There used to be a guy named "Pooh Bear" who was this sweet yet ornery semi-homeless guy who weighed about 300 pounds but was the "sweetest bear around"... I used to send him postcards from my travels around the world care of La Rocca's, and the bartenders there would give them to Pooh and he'd cry because someone thought of him. He died recently, but his legend lives on (ask any of the bar staff for stories). I guess it used to be an old Mafia hang-out, but now it's a hang-out for soccer hooligans. A quick walk from Fisherman's Wharf, the more commercial part of North Beach, and right by Bimbo's, La Rocca's is a little out of place, but that's the way it likes it.
author: Christy M.

description: One of the nicest bathrooms I've seen in a bar in a long time, very spacious and clean. The aromas are tantalizing! Outside of the bathroom the smell changes to stale beer and dudes. Lots of dudes and beer here...
author: Nicolas H.

description: This was the first place my roommate and I came for a drink after moving into the city.  We now go at least twice a week and consistently end our nights with a shot poured by our favorite local bartenders. Comfortable atmosphere, interesting people and cheap drinks... great North Beach establishment.
author: Corrie M.

description: I hate it when bars market themselves as places where the "tourists meet the locals", or have one of those obnoxious "THIS IS IT" signs, how much more of a trap could this be?
author: Chris S.

description:
LaRocca"s! My dad first brought me to LaRocca's. He was a regular, and everyone there always told me he was "A man's Man". My dad's name is Bob Kelly, and though he passed 15 years ago, he is still remembered.  In fact they have a picture of him on the wall,  I expected when I visited 2 years ago that it would have been removed by now, But that is LaRocca's, a friend for life. 
The LaRocca's themselves are no longer there, and though my Dad is Irish, I remember him telling me that no matter what kind of threat I faced, or trouble I may ever get in,  he had "friends " who could "help me out". In fact,the LaRocca's had a family band, which played at my wedding reception.  Guess you could say they were kind of my extended family.
My kids and I moved to Arizona, but even they take special pleasure, any time they are in the Bay Area, to stop by LaRocca's, where their Grandad is still remembered.
If any of you longtime patrons remember him, Bob Kelly, it would please me greatly to hear from you! I am his second daughter, Patricia, and email is trishep104@gmail.com
LRocca's Rocks!
author: Trish S.

description: good drinking bar. whisky and a beer? don't mind if i do
author: Hank B.

description: It's never my idea, but I have spent many a night at this bar.  This is a bar I used to go to when I was underage.  Now that I'm legal to drink, it's not my first choice, but it's at least decent.  The set up can be a little awkward and there's always a huge line for the bathroom, but if you can get a seat at the bar or in the window, you're golden.  The bartenders are cool and the drinks are stiff.  I come here when I go to Bimbos, for a daytime drinking marathon, or when friends drag me there.  Ask the bartender for dice and play midnight at the bar.
author: angela k.

description: the perfect place to hang out before several choice tourists and the entire bar staff spills over into my living room and wake my evil roommate by dancing to Prince.
author: Nathan G.

description: This is a fun bar to go to if there is a big event in the area (ie. Cobbs or Bimbo's). If you go on a dead night it can be quite depressing. I have been coming to this bar for a long time and love it. The bartenders are cool and the owner is out of control (in a good way). It attracts a good local crowd. Even though they say that it is where the "Tourists meet the locals" I never see any tourists, just lots of locals. I cannot go into this bar without seeing someone that I went to high school with. They have another catch phrase there - "Drink with Dignity". I prefer to lose my dignity, and this is a perfect place to do it.
author: Paul H.
